sentence: To what extent can Adobe’s (ADBE) Cloud momentum continue?

It’s been a little over four years since Adobe, which offers a broad range of software and services (including Photoshop) used by professionals, transformed its business from selling software by the box to a cloud-based subscription model.
Since that conversion, Adobe shares have skyrocketed more than 400%.
Take a look at the chart, courtesy of Yahoo!.
The San Jose, Calif.-based software giant is set to report first quarter fiscal 2018 earnings results after the closing bell Thursday.

Adobe’s strong cloud execution, particular in the midst of intense competition from the likes of Oracle (ORCL) and Salesforce (CRM), is something I’ve pointed out on numerous occasions, including shooting down notions that ADBE stock was too expensive at around $145.
Adobe shares now trade for $220, rising some 50% since my recommendation.
Valuation concerns have again been raised as Adobe this year has broken above the $100 billion market cap, putting it in an exclusive club among software companies.
The stock, however, currently trades at 35 times fiscal 2018 estimates of $6.28 per share, which is almost twice the average stock in the S&P 500 index.
Microsoft (MSFT), by comparison, trades at a multiple that is ten points lower.
That said, Adobe’s valuation pales in the comparison to Salesforce’s forward P/E of 62.
And not only does Adobe’s revenue growth estimates for 20% matches that of Salesforce, the profit estimate growth for Adobe at 45% is only five percentage points lower than Salesforce’s 50%.
For my money, Adobe’s risk-versus-reward profile, especially when combined with its best-of-breed status among the digital cloud space, is more attractive.
For the quarter that ended January, Wall Street expects Adobe to report $1.44 per share on revenue of $2.05 billion, translating to year-over-year growth of 53% and 21.7%, respectively.
For the full year, ending November, earnings are expected to rise 45.7% year over year to $6.28 per share, while full-year revenue of $8.77 billion would climb 20% year over year.
Last quarter Adobe’s Digital Media revenue surged 29% to $1.39 billion, while Digital Media ARR (Annualized Recurring Revenues) reached a company record $5.23 billion.
These gains were driven by better-than-expected demand for the company’s Creative Cloud and Document Cloud business lines.
And analysts, targeting Q1 Digital Media ARR revenuer of $5.63 billion, expect this trend to continue, driven by more organic revenue growth from Adobe’s cloud model.
Elsewhere, investors will gauge for improvements in Adobe Analytics Cloud and Adobe Advertising Cloud segment.
Analysts expect the Marketing Cloud segment to deliver revenues of $552 million, compared to $550 million in Q4.

All told, thanks to the management’s well-timed decision to shift the legacy business to Cloud subscription model, Adobe, which continues to deliver top and bottom-line growth, while consistently raising guidance, has been one of the best success stories on the market, driven by large Marketing Cloud customers such as Verizon (VZ), UPS (UPS) and Pandora (P), among others.
And until there are clearer signs that the Cloud has peaked, I will continue to recommend these shares.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
